channel.title: Communication
channel.description: I don't think this is much of a discussion but could lead to something, I have had this question for a long time for being so imaginative. What I was wondering is what if on Earth, each species of animals could talk to eachother. We just haven't found a way to communicate. It's probably not possible, but don't you think it would be interesting. Back to the god question, if god was real, would he make it so that we could not communicate with other animals but we still havent learned to break the communication block lol. Or anotherr type of maml could be capable of learning a language, for example a monkey, but they haven't caught on yet. It sounds silly but think about it! If it turns out to be stupid then tell me and I'll delete it. It's just something that has been on my mind.

item.title: Communication
item.dc:creator: @kronixz kronikz
item.description:
@kronixz wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:39, topic:460340”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=563261.msg4108068#msg4108068 date=1348238406]

To say it in another way, would other dogs know that your dog is talking about the mail man?

No I don’t believe they would. However, if other dogs lived here, they would eventually know.

Are you saying they could become like humans in that aspect? Their phisiology is far too different (that I know off) for communications like our own and would most likely become extinct from external factors before they develope the ability. It’d take millions of years, many many many millions of years. I’m not an expert in the department or anything all I know is the bark is intended for primal functions whereas our own voice that I know of at least is actually meant for communications similar to monkeys although of course ours is more advanced (of course theirs could be, I’m no monkey expert either).
[/quote]

Wasn’t comparing them to humans at all, simply answering the question. If other dogs lived here, they would eventually realize that when my dog makes that type of bark, the mailman comes. A learned behavior but it stops there. The dog was also bred as a watchdog so this may be normal for it’s breed.

Also, although my dog can’t talk back, he definitely understands many words. I don’t know if understand is the right word, but he certainly knows more commands/names of places/names of people than a small child would.[/quote]

To back you up on that, whenever I say a certain sentence to my dog, she immediately knows what I am talking about. For example,
“want to go in the car” she sprints for the door and gets super excited. Or if your mad at here and tell her “go to your room” she will get a sad face and slowly start walking to her little cushion thing. Sometimes I started realising this and maybe if i said “go to your room” in the tone I would say if was saying “want to go in the car” maybe she would head for the door, but no she still understood the words. This goes with many other sentences aswell.
(my dog is a poodle schnauzer mix.)

But cats… there dumb (i hate cats)

Read full topic

No I don’t believe they would. However, if other dogs lived here, they would eventually know.

Are you saying they could become like humans in that aspect? Their phisiology is far too different (that I know off) for communications like our own and would most likely become extinct from external factors before they develope the ability. It’d take millions of years, many many many millions of years. I’m not an expert in the department or anything all I know is the bark is intended for primal functions whereas our own voice that I know of at least is actually meant for communications similar to monkeys although of course ours is more advanced (of course theirs could be, I’m no monkey expert either).

Yeah what you said is true

item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

[quote=“Kidpaparoach, post:38, topic:460340”][quote author=jme link=topic=563261.msg4107662#msg4107662 date=1348176404]

To say it in another way, would other dogs know that your dog is talking about the mail man?

No I don’t believe they would. However, if other dogs lived here, they would eventually know.

[/quote]
Are you saying they could become like humans in that aspect? Their phisiology is far too different (that I know off) for communications like our own and would most likely become extinct from external factors before they develope the ability. It’d take millions of years, many many many millions of years. I’m not an expert in the department or anything all I know is the bark is intended for primal functions whereas our own voice that I know of at least is actually meant for communications similar to monkeys although of course ours is more advanced (of course theirs could be, I’m no monkey expert either).[/quote]

Wasn’t comparing them to humans at all, simply answering the question. If other dogs lived here, they would eventually realize that when my dog makes that type of bark, the mailman comes. A learned behavior but it stops there. The dog was also bred as a watchdog so this may be normal for it’s breed.

Also, although my dog can’t talk back, he definitely understands many words. I don’t know if understand is the right word, but he certainly knows more commands/names of places/names of people than a small child would.

item.dc:creator: @kronixz kronikz
item.description:
@kronixz wrote:

[quote=“ranger squad, post:35, topic:460340”][quote author=KroniKz_ link=topic=563261.msg4107614#msg4107614 date=1348173743]

There still would be signs and books at school that have the alphabet and videos for babies that tell u what they mean lol. They whole world would be like “apel” to the picture apple lmao.

Pronunciation has to be learned too

still videos on those
[/quote]

Hmm, I guess. But language would still take many hundreds of years to redevelop.[/quote]
Well once you learn pain and go “OWWWW” and start hearing noises, you will try to use it on others. Since humans are so smart we could do it again with no knowledge, it’s like how hellen keller or however you spell it said whaaahterrr with out knowing what she was saying or hearing. After that she wrote a book. That really shows how a human can learn without hearing/seeing. She learned herself from sign language basically. If humans learned to talk with noises like dolphons or something, don’t you think dolphons can eventually make there own noise language. They could be the humans of the sea :o

I just re read this paragraph and its really off subject and i start something new every sentence, my bad

Read full topic

item.title: Communication
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

[quote=“KroniKz_, post:30, topic:460340”][quote author=ranger squad link=topic=563261.msg4107507#msg4107507 date=1348166731]

Well considering before we created different languages we communicated as other animals would, why would communication be difficult? Although it may take time, i do believe it is possible.

But frogs havent developed computers, cars, space shuttles…

I am fairly certain that is irrelevant to the entire conversation of communication.

I am fairly certain that it’s not. You said that if we developed enough to talk properly, that animals could do the same. I pointed out other ways in which we have developed where animals haven’t.
Just because it disagrees with you, that doesn’t make it irrelevant.

Also, the talking snake was the devil, not God.

Actually i said that we used to talk as other animals would, not that they could do the same. It would just take time to be able to communicate like they did once again.

No, even if we revert to “ug ug”, we won’t be able to communicate with animals any more than at present. Just because (if we reverted) our languages use sounds, like animals’ languages do, that doesn’t mean we can communicate with them. I have never seen tigers talk to elephants.

Also, do you really think that our brain capacity hasn’t changed since caveman days and that we could devolve to talk using primitive sounds? The only real thing to cause that would be a mental virus pandemic which causes everyone’s speech memory to be wiped (all language forgotten) or for a complete wipeout of the human race except pre-speech babies.
[/quote]
What virus would male us only forget languages lol, unless we had total amnesia were we forget everything we ever knew.
In that case, we would learn again just as we did before![/quote]
afaik there are viruses that affect certain parts of the brain, so why wouldn’t there be possibility for a virus to only affect the part of the brain which controls language? And we probably wouldn’t learn too easily - it’s taken thousands of years to develop our language, and if everyone in the world had forgotten what language was, and had no way of easily communicating (it’s hard enough to learn a language when you can talk about it, imagine creating one!) then it would take a long time.

Read full topic

item.description:
@kronixz wrote:

[quote=“ranger squad, post:29, topic:460340”][quote author=amy_webb link=topic=563261.msg4107246#msg4107246 date=1348133160]

Well considering before we created different languages we communicated as other animals would, why would communication be difficult? Although it may take time, i do believe it is possible.

But frogs havent developed computers, cars, space shuttles…

I am fairly certain that is irrelevant to the entire conversation of communication.

I am fairly certain that it’s not. You said that if we developed enough to talk properly, that animals could do the same. I pointed out other ways in which we have developed where animals haven’t.
Just because it disagrees with you, that doesn’t make it irrelevant.

Also, the talking snake was the devil, not God.

Actually i said that we used to talk as other animals would, not that they could do the same. It would just take time to be able to communicate like they did once again.
[/quote]
No, even if we revert to “ug ug”, we won’t be able to communicate with animals any more than at present. Just because (if we reverted) our languages use sounds, like animals’ languages do, that doesn’t mean we can communicate with them. I have never seen tigers talk to elephants.

Also, do you really think that our brain capacity hasn’t changed since caveman days and that we could devolve to talk using primitive sounds? The only real thing to cause that would be a mental virus pandemic which causes everyone’s speech memory to be wiped (all language forgotten) or for a complete wipeout of the human race except pre-speech babies.[/quote]
What virus would male us only forget languages lol, unless we had total amnesia were we forget everything we ever knew.
In that case, we would learn again just as we did before!

Read full topic

item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

[quote=“amy_webb, post:26, topic:460340”][quote author=ranger squad link=topic=563261.msg4107188#msg4107188 date=1348121236]

Well considering before we created different languages we communicated as other animals would, why would communication be difficult? Although it may take time, i do believe it is possible.

But frogs havent developed computers, cars, space shuttles…

I am fairly certain that is irrelevant to the entire conversation of communication.

I am fairly certain that it’s not. You said that if we developed enough to talk properly, that animals could do the same. I pointed out other ways in which we have developed where animals haven’t.
Just because it disagrees with you, that doesn’t make it irrelevant.

Also, the talking snake was the devil, not God.
[/quote]
Actually i said that we used to talk as other animals would, not that they could do the same. It would just take time to be able to communicate like they did once again.[/quote]
No, even if we revert to “ug ug”, we won’t be able to communicate with animals any more than at present. Just because (if we reverted) our languages use sounds, like animals’ languages do, that doesn’t mean we can communicate with them. I have never seen tigers talk to elephants.

Also, do you really think that our brain capacity hasn’t changed since caveman days and that we could devolve to talk using primitive sounds? The only real thing to cause that would be a mental virus pandemic which causes everyone’s speech memory to be wiped (all language forgotten) or for a complete wipeout of the human race except pre-speech babies.

item.description:

jme: Do you think the barks is a language, or have the different barks just gotten different meanings for your dog only?
To say it in another way, would other dogs know that your dog is talking about the mail man?

Read full topic

item.title: Communication
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Through sounds, body language, and phermones is how animals communicate. Some of it is instinct or biological, and some of it is learned. We can pick up on this and communicate back already given you spend enough time with the animal.

I always like the way my dog has special barks. A distinct bark for the mail man. A distinct bark for dogs walking down the street. A distinct bark for when a guest is coming, and a distinct one for my mother. I can tell which scenario it is simply by his bark

Read full topic

item.title: Communication
item.dc:creator: @F_A_I_L_S Fails
item.description:
@F_A_I_L_S wrote:

As Niall and jme stated, we can communicate with animals through sounds, sign language, etc. This thread made me think of the movie ‘UP’ when the dog was speaking through his collar. When that movie was ‘released’ I was 10-11 and I always wandered if it was possible. I had a very vivid imagination as a child. Anyways, now that I think about it, I do believe it’s possible, then again, I don’t.

Read full topic

Yeah, I doubt it will be anytime soon. Scientists are too interested in getting off this planet, rather than making our own planet better.

item.title: Communication
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“runescape sucks, post:18, topic:460340”]I always wondered if you put a human into a group of animals, if he would learn their language.

Of course Tarzan made me think this.[/quote]I thought the same after watching Tarzan a week ago. At the same time, I was also wondering why aren’t anything from other cartoons/movies being considered or tested? Like ironman, it’s not impossible to make tiny rockets that have enough power to lift over 170 pounds and protect the legs from catching fire. It’s merely an idea which may not be taken seriously for a while, but it still has potential. Or even hovering skateboards! I was wondering that when I was a kid, if engineers could make a strong enough fan to at least hold half a human, and make it small enough to fit under a board and cover half the board.

Read full topic
